Without directly questioning the creators, who WILL have answers (unlike God, who we are not supposed to test, just blindly swallow His unproven promises and unfulfilled prophecies), we can never really know their true intent. It's easy to see correlations between Christian mythology and The Matrix; however, I can't accept that it's really that simple. The Matrix could perhaps more correctly be defined as a fusion of philosophies and mythological interpretation of humanity's existence throughout time. The Bible is not the only book in the world with false prophecies and messiahs, and if you think it is, do climb out from under your rock. A rpophecy is a common religious idea, even an idea used in popular culture. There is a prophecy in Star Wars, for example. One can argue that it has or has not been fulfilled by Anakin or even Luke, but that's another thread for another time. 
 
 One argues that they are seeing the film The Matrix for what they want it to be, i.e. Christian mythology, interpreting Daoism, etc. However, to do so is to miss the point: how can we fully know that what we see, hear, feel, touch, taste, and understand is reality? To have complete faith is to deny that there is any other possibility, and to do that is to admit an inability to be humble. For the Christian, how can he/she know that God's word is really what He claims it to be? Has He not tested His follows, misguiding them? If He created All, then evil, too, fits into His resume. How can a just creator willingly test us like that?
 
 All I'm saying is this: everything deserves scrutiny and skepticism. Including God.
